topic.name: Global Economics
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Global Economics in History & Social Studies

objectives.objective_text: Identify rich countries and poor countries.
Name clean water and schools as things everyone needs.
Identify the Human Development Index (HDI).
Identify money from other countries (Euro, Yen, Peso).
Name the Dollar.
Identify the Euro.
Identify the internet connecting everyone.
Name famous brands found everywhere (Coke, Nike).
Identify Multinational Corporations.
Identify labels that say 'Made in China' or 'Made in Mexico'.
Name ships that carry boxes across the ocean.
Identify a Trade Deficit.
Identify that Jesus loves the poor.
Name giving food and clothes as helping.
Identify Christian relief organizations.
Recall that we should help poor neighbors.
Observe pictures of life in developing nations.
Recall that you have to change money when you travel.
Observe that different money looks different.
Recall that the world feels smaller.
Observe that we can talk to anyone instantly.
Recall that we buy things from other countries.
Observe bananas in the grocery store (they don't grow here).
Recall that we should share.
Observe that not everyone has a home.
Summarize the difference between Developed and Developing nations.
Explain what 'Infrastructure' is (roads, power, internet).
Explain the role of Microfinance.
Defend the role of property rights in development.
Summarize what an Exchange Rate is.
Explain why the dollar gets stronger or weaker.
Explain Hyperinflation in history (Zimbabwe, Venezuela).
Defend the stability provided by the dollar standard.
Summarize what Globalization is.
Explain the Global Supply Chain (parts from everywhere).
Explain the backlash against globalization.
Defend the cultural benefits of exchange.
Summarize Imports and Exports.
Explain why we trade (we have what they need, they have what we need).
Explain the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Defend the moral case for trade (lifting nations out of poverty).
Summarize the biblical command to care for the widow and orphan.
Explain the difference between relief (emergency) and development (long term).
Explain the role of the local church in relief.
Defend the dignity of the poor (Imago Dei).
Compare Per Capita Income.
Analyze the causes of poverty (corruption, war, lack of rule of law).
Interpret the 'Poverty Trap'.
Connect education to economic growth.
Compare a cheap currency (good for selling) with a strong one (good for buying).
Analyze how exchange rates affect tourism and trade.
Interpret a currency conversion chart.
Connect the US Dollar as the 'Reserve Currency'.
Compare local culture with global culture.
Analyze the cultural homogenization caused by globalization.
Interpret the impact of shipping containers on trade.
Connect globalization to the spread of ideas and religion.
Compare Free Trade with Protectionism (keeping jobs at home).
Analyze the concept of Absolute vs. Comparative Advantage.
Interpret the function of Tariffs and Quotas.
Connect trade wars to prices in stores.
Compare giving a fish vs. teaching to fish.
Analyze the causes of systemic poverty.
Interpret 'When Helping Hurts' (doing harm by giving wrongly).
Connect the Gospel to holistic restoration.
Evaluate the 'Institutions' theory of wealth (Acemoglu).
Evaluate the role of the IMF (International Monetary Fund).
Evaluate the environmental impact of global shipping.
Evaluate the impact of outsourcing on domestic labor.
Evaluate the effectiveness of government welfare vs. private charity.
Construct a critique of Foreign Aid (effective vs. harmful).
Synthesize the biblical mandate for justice and mercy in development.
Construct an explanation of floating vs. pegged exchange rates.
Synthesize the impact of currency manipulation.
Construct an evaluation of the winners and losers of globalization.
Synthesize the future of globalization in a polarized world.
Construct an argument for the benefits of global trade.
Synthesize the tension between economic efficiency and national security.
Construct a strategy for effective poverty alleviation.
Synthesize a biblical theology of wealth and poverty.
